qas.question: What limits the sensitivity of infrared telescopes on Earth?
To somewhat avoid the water vapor in the atmosphere, where can an observatory be sited?
Along with aircraft, what object can be used to carry a telescope aloft?
What sorts of telescopes completely avoid water vapor in Earth's atmosphere?
What limits the sensitivity of high altitude observatories?
What is the ideal location for atmospheric windows?
What kind of telescopes avoid absorbing infrared radiation?
Where can you place an observatory to avoid the atmospheric window?
What absorbs infrared radiation from space away from high altitude?

context: The sensitivity of Earth-based infrared telescopes is significantly limited by <a0_0><b4_0><b8_0>water vapor in the atmosphere<b4_0/><a0_0/>,<b8_0/> which absorbs a portion of the infrared radiation arriving from space outside of selected atmospheric windows. This limitation can be partially alleviated by placing the telescope observatory <a1_0><b7_0>at a high altitude<b7_0/><a1_0/>, or by carrying the telescope aloft with a <a2_0>balloon<a2_0/> or an aircraft. <a3_0><b6_0>Space telescopes<b6_0/><a3_0/> do not suffer from this handicap, and so <b5_0>outer space<b5_0/> is considered the ideal location for infrared astronomy.
